q1.question:
The events at this location became widely known fifty years later thanks to a book by Stuart
Lake. The incident here resulted in the death of Tom and Frank McLaury as well as Billy
Clanton, though the "law" side suffered no casualties among Doc Holliday or Wyatt Earp. For 10
points, name this place in Tombstone, Arizona where an 1881 "shootout" took place.

The proposal to join this body was opposed in the Lodge Reservations, which specifically
objected to Article X (ten) of its charter, committing all members to repel any aggression against
one. William Borah's Irreconcilables movement drummed up public resistance to American
participation in this organization. For 10 points, name this ineffective international body created
by the Treaty of Versailles, which the U.S. never joined despite Woodrow Wilson's protestations.

Following Ross Perot's most successful attempt at the Presidency, Perot embarked on a
campaign against this legislation, predicting it would cause a "giant sucking sound." This
legislation was championed in a televised debate by Al Gore, and its architects included Carlos
Salinas and Brian Mulroney. For 10 points, name this continental trade pact.

This man launched the anti-hunger Operation Breadbasket as a project of his
"Rainbow/PUSH" coalition. In the 1980s, he ran for the Democratic Presidential nomination
twice and was dogged by reports of anti-Semitism during the New York primary. For 10 points,
name this former confidante of Martin Luther King, Jr. who became a prominent civil rights
spokesman.

When it became apparent that this event had failed, a disgusted Erich Ludendorff simply
walked away, leading its main organizer to be sentenced to the Landsberg, where Mein Kampf
was written. For 10 points, name this failed 1923 attempt by Adolf Hitler to seize power in
Germany by leading an uprising at a Munich drinking venue.

This man's great-grandfather raised the 1st Mississippi Partisan Rangers in the Civil War and
wrote The White Rose of Memphis. This author used that ancestor as the model for the
protagonist of The Unvanquished, Colonel Sartoris. For 10 points, name this Mississippi-born
novelist of "A Rose for Emily" and The Sound and the Fury.

This man said he planned to use a Kärcher pressure-washer to "clean out" suburbs. In 2014,
this former leader of the UMP was questioned by police for alleged corruption in a judicial
appointment in Monaco. He lost a close re-election bid in 2012 to his left-wing rival François
Hollande (pr. frah-SWAH oh-LAHND). For 10 points, name this former President of France.

Florida developer Henry Flagler got rich as a business partner of this man. Frederick Taylor
Gates advised him on how to direct his philanthropy, which included providing the startup funds
for Spelman College and the University of Chicago. For 10 points, name this businessman who
was attacked by Ida Tarbell as a monopolist after founding Standard Oil.

In 2014, a Senate candidate from this state was criticized for posting graphic X-rays on his
website; that second cousin of Barack Obama, Milton Wolf, failed to win the Republican
nomination here. This state is where independent Greg Orman is seeking to unseat incumbent Pat
Roberts. For 10 points, name this state governed by Sam Brownback from Topeka.

An early practitioner of this art form was satirized as "elevating" it from a hot-air balloon in
an engraving by Honoré Daumier (pr. oh-no-RAY dow-mee-EY). This art form was used to
depict The Steerage by Alfred Stieglitz and Moon and Half Dome by a later American leader of
f/64 ("eff sixty-four"). For 10 points, name this art form used by Ansel Adams to produce prints.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) The "condottiere" (pr. cahn-DOE-tee-AIR-ee) were what type of soldiers, who fought
most of the wars of Renaissance Italy and were often of English origin and whose use was
warned against by Machiavelli?

tossup.question:
In 1850, a seeming discrepancy in this scientist’s work was resolved by Stanislao Cannizzaro.
This man’s breakthrough was realizing the distinction between atoms and molecules in a gas,
causing this veteran of the Piedmont uprising to be the namesake of the number 6.022 times 10
to the 23rd. For 10 points, identify this discoverer of the number of particles in a mole.

bonus.question:
Avogadro was the first to correctly determine the chemical formula for what substance,
which was moved against the force of gravity by Archimedes’s Screw?

tossup.question:
This queen came to the throne at age six, leading to the creation of a regency council
dominated by Axel Oxenstierna (pr. OCK-sens-TURR-nuh). In 1654, this queen shocked
Europe by abdicating her throne and converting to Catholicism, after which she lived out her life
in Rome. For 10 points, name this daughter of Gustavus Adolphus, an “enlightened monarch” of
Sweden.

bonus.question:
Christina’s energetic studies with what philosopher of Discourse on Method, whom she
summoned to Sweden and often woke before dawn, are thought to have caused his death?

tossup.question:
The Eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution copied nearly verbatim this text’s prohibition
on “excessive bail and cruel and unusual punishments.” This document guaranteed freedom of
speech and the right to bear arms, and it also banned Catholics from succeeding to the throne.
For 10 points, name this 1689 law which outlined liberties prior to the Glorious Revolution.

bonus.question:
What editor of The North Briton whose slogan was “No Liberty, No King” caused
repeated scandals in 1760s England by invoking the English Bill of Rights in his campaign
against George III?

tossup.question:
This god's oracle was located at Dodona. Phidias used the ivory-and-gold material
chryselephantine to depict this god for one of the Wonders of the Ancient World. This god was
believed to have survived the cannibalism of his father Cronus by being swapped with a stone.
For 10 points, name this thunder god and head of the Greek pantheon.

bonus.question:
Another Wonder of the Ancient World was the Colossus of Rhodes, which depicted
what Titan god of the sun?

tossup.question:
This man was approached by Thomas Edison's agent Theo Wangemann in 1889, leading him
to make the first-ever audio recording by a leading composer. This composer relied on Martin
Luther's translation of the Bible as the text for his German Requiem. For 10 points, name this
composer whom Hans von Bulow first grouped with Beethoven and Bach as the "Three Bs."

bonus.question:
Brahms was born in what city, now the second largest city by population of Germany
and once a major center of the Hanseatic League?

tossup.question:
This politician purged opponents in the "Anti-Rightist Campaign" after encouraging dissenters
to identify themselves in the Hundred Flowers movement. Following news of the Secret Speech,
this politician led his country away from Nikita Khrushchev's Soviet Union in the late 1950s. For
10 points, name this Long March leader and longtime "chairman" of Communist China.

bonus.question:
What late 1950s program championed by Mao involved producing steel in backyard
furnaces in a disastrous attempt to overtake Soviet and American industrial capacity?

tossup.question:
This theory was advocated by John Needham due to a faulty experimental design. Lazzaro
Spallanzani argued against this theory by showing that Needham had failed to entirely seal the
boiled flask used before observing “animalcules.” For 10 points, name this theory finally put to
rest by Louis Pasteur, which holds that rotting food directly creates life.

bonus.question:
What scientist, the namesake of cells found around nerves, coined the dogma that “all
cells come from pre-existing cells” following the collapse of spontaneous generation theory?

tossup.question:
In 1905, Germany's Kaiser Wilhelm II landed at this country's port of Tangier to support its
independence, causing a crisis with France. This country is also home to the headgear namesake
Fez and to the site of a January 1943 Allied summit that first formulated the "unconditional
surrender" doctrine. For 10 points, name this country which hosted the Casablanca Conference.

bonus.question:
The next Allied conference was held in what city, which was planned by Pierre
L'Enfant and burned down after the Battle of Bladensburg in 1814?

questions.question:
England's South Sea Bubble scandal of 1720...
Arose over a company which transported what kind of people in the "Middle Passage" after
forcible abduction from Africa?
Led to the creation of what office, later held by Margaret Thatcher and David Cameron?
answer: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

questions.question: Occurred during the reign of what first Hanoverian king?

Led to the ascension of what party, which opposed the Tories in the eighteenth-century British
party system?

Temporarily soured the English investor class on what form of business entity which preceded
corporations and was prominent during the Age of Exploration?
Arose from an attempt to exploit the Treaty of Utrecht, which ended what war in 1713?
Was resolved by what politician who dominated the British government until 1742?
Caused the creation of what institution, which manages UK monetary policy?

In Italy after World War II, who or what was the...
Ideology advocated by the Red Brigades terrorist group and Italy's neighbor Yugoslavia?
Organized crime phenomenon which was curtailed in the "Maxi trial?"
Organization formed by the Maastricht Treaty which Italy was an architect of?
Western military alliance which orchestrated Operation Gladio in Italy?

Media mogul who became Italy's right-wing prime minister three times and was frequently
charged with corruption?
Milan-based designer who founded what is now Italy's largest men's fashion house in 1975?
Umbrella auto manufacturer which now owns Ferrari, Maserati, and Chrysler?
Name commonly given to the period of political violence from 1969 to the mid-1980s?

U.S. President Millard Fillmore…
Was the last President to belong to neither of what two parties?
Succeeded what “Old Rough and Ready” Mexican War hero, who died in office?
Was the first President inaugurated after the dedication of what 555-foot obelisk in D.C.?
Sent what "Commodore" to open trade with Japan?
Recognized Utah as a territory under the leadership of what Mormon church president?
Signed what omnibus bill which sought to resolve free-slave state concerns?
Attempted to regain the Presidency in 1856 under the banner of what third party?
Approved the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty, which concerned the future construction of what route?

parts:
(30 pts) This body was originally under the influence of John Pym and the radical "Five
Members," and it was convened to raise money following the Bishops' Wars. This body
steadily lost members, ending up named sardonically for Nicholas (20 pts)

Barebones, after its
moderate delegates were removed in Pride's Purge to create the (10 pts)

Rump Parliament. For 10
points, name this Parliament which oversaw the English Civil War and is named because it sat
from 1640 to 1660.

(30 pts) This man expanded his Keystone Bridge Company into his business empire, which
greatly profited from introducing the Bessemer process to widespread use in America. This
man's 1899 article "The (20 pts)

Gospel of Wealth" outlined his philanthropic plans, which
included founding several (10 pts)

library systems now named for him. For 10 points, name this
Scottish immigrant who became the greatest steel magnate of the late nineteenth century.

(30 pts) Alexey Leonov posits that the training crash which killed this man in 1968 was caused by
an accidental near-miss with another fighter jet. This man, who was selected out of twenty
candidates from (20 pts)

Star City, whistled the patriotic song "The Motherland Hears" while
re-entering the atmosphere aboard (10 pts)

Vostok 1. For 10 points, name this Soviet cosmonaut
who, in 1961, became the first human to leave the Earth's atmosphere.

(30 pts) A 2001 panel of experts in this sport named Regla Torres and Lorenzo Bernardi among
its three best players of all time. William Morgan invented this game in 1895 as a less
physical use of (20 pts)

basketball courts. Al Scates is the most successful coach in this sport,
and was the trainer of the generally regarded best-ever player at this sport, (10 pts)

Karch
Kiraly. For 10 points, name this game in which a libero, blockers, and setters play across an
elevated net.

(30 pts) John Brooks Henderson was the initial special prosecutor in charge of resolving this
scandal, but was replaced with James Broadhead after appearing too incorruptible. This
scandal was organized in St. Louis and involved personal (20 pts)

secretary Orville Babcock.
Treasury secretary Benjamin (10 pts)

Bristow exposed this affair in 1875. For 10 points, name this
scandal involving the embezzlement of tax revenues on liquor which came to discredit the Grant
administration.

(30 pts) A road extending from Castrum Truentinum to the Aurelian Walls of Rome was named
for this substance, whose transportation was the impetus for building some of the oldest
known (20 pts)
roads. This substance was traded to the north in exchange for gold from the (10 pts)

African interior, especially by the Ghana empire. For 10 points, identify this formerly valuable
substance which can now be easily retrieved from natural sources such as seawater and is often
iodized.

(30 pts) This man successfully completed the "red line" map as part of the plan for a "Cape to
Cairo railway." This man was sent as the agent of the Rothschild company to (20 pts)

Kimberley, where he spent seventeen years buying competing diamond fields. He founded
the (10 pts)

De Beers company to cement his monopoly over the industry. For 10 points, name this
British colonialist in South Africa who endowed a series of scholarships for foreign students at
Oxford.

(30 pts) Guns fired from this building ended the Battle of the Faubourg St. Antoine (pr. foo-BOO
sont AHN-twan) during the Fronde. This building is where the Marquis de (20 pts)

Sade enraged
crowds by claiming a plot to massacre its inhabitants. Only seven politically unimportant (10 pts)

prisoners were found inside when it was stormed on July 14, 1789. For 10 points, name this
Paris prison which was destroyed to start the French Revolution.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) In 1595, the Tooth of the Buddha was moved to a reliquary on this island, where the
Kingdom of Kandy long held out against colonization. In the twentieth century, this island
had the world's first (20 pts)
female prime minister, and its (10 pts)

Sinhalese majority fought a
protracted war with a terrorist group that invented suicide bombing. For 10 points, name this
island country where the Tamil Tigers fought against the government at Colombo, often spilling
into nearby India.
